entry.title: Release of JooFlux r1
entry.content:
The Dynamid members are pleased to announce the second release of JooFlux.

JooFlux r1 can be obtained from https://github.com/dynamid/jooflux and is made available under the terms of the Mozilla Public License Version 2.0.

This release improves the compatibility with existing JVM-based applications. It also features additions to facilitate the implementation of remote management applications.

We encourage the wider researchers and practitioners community to report any issue with JooFlux, and contribute bug fixes and improvements.

entry.title: LavaJUG
entry.content:
Dynamid members went to the mythical LavaJUG to talk about invokedynamic, JooFlux and Golo.

This was also the first public demonstration of the Golo programming language.

Great crowd, great place, we had a lot of fun!

entry.title: JooFlux @ ComPAS, Grenoble, 2013
entry.content:
The current state of our research on the JooFlux project was presented last week at the ComPAS 2013 conference.

Our research paper was published in the CFSE track that gathers the French specialists in the larger field of operating systems.

Lots of positive feedback on our works, we couldn't be happier!

Here are the slides, in French:

entry.title: JooFlux article accepted at CFSE 2013
entry.content:
We are glad to report that our first peer-reviewed scientific paper for JooFlux has been accepted in the CFSE 2013 conference.

CFSE is the top French national conference on operating system research. The program committee comprises big names in the field, the kind with proven research and industrial track records, so this is definitely a strong achievement for Dynamid.

Our next-step is to take the thoroughly-detailed reviews that we obtained and target a top international conference.

entry.title: Nighthacking
entry.content:
Dynamid member Julien Ponge recorded a NightHacking session with Stephen Chin from Oracle.

Stephen was doing a tour of Europe before ending at the Devoxx conference. He had a stop in Lyon and the LyonJUG arranged the interview.

During the 1 hour informal discussion, Julien talked about bytecode manipulation on the JVM and even demoed JooFlux at one point.
